question: Is the Sun a medium-sized star located near the edge of the Milky Way galaxy?

content.source_1: The Sun is a G2V (yellow dwarf) main-sequence star with about one solar mass and radius; in educational astronomy it is often described as an “average-sized” star.
content.source_2: The Solar System sits in the Orion Arm (Orion Spur) about 26,000–27,000 light-years from the Milky Way’s center—well outside the central bulge, in what astronomers often call the Galaxy’s outer disk or “galactic suburbs.”
content.source_3: The Milky Way shows a negative radial metallicity gradient: on average, stars and gas in the outer disk have lower heavy-element abundances (metallicity) than those toward the inner disk and bulge.
content.source_4: High-precision spectroscopy measures the Sun’s photospheric iron abundance at approximately [Fe/H] ≈ 0 dex (by definition); nearby thin-disk stars have a metallicity distribution centered slightly below solar, around [Fe/H] ≈ −0.1 to −0.2.
content.source_5: The Sun’s overall heavy-element mass fraction is Z ≈ 0.013–0.014, consistent with near-solar metallicity and typical of many solar-neighborhood thin-disk stars rather than the metal-poor tail of the distribution.
content.source_6: The Sun orbits the Milky Way roughly once every 225–250 million years at a galactocentric radius near the solar circle, far from the crowded central regions.

answer: The Sun is a medium-sized star near the edge of the Milky Way Galaxy.
